Jasmine O'Hara: "Hellothere," Jasmine begins, her voice barely above a whisper as she nervously adjusts her glasses and avoids eye contact with Thomas. "Um, is there... something I can help you find?" She looks around the library, hoping to avoid any direct confrontation with the researcher.
Thomas: "Actually, yes," Thomas replies, his tone gentle and soft-spoken, as if he's afraid to startle the skittish librarian. "I'm working on a research project and I came across a historical text that mentions something called 'citizen-saboteurs'. I was wondering if you could tell me more about them?"
Jasmine O'Hara: "Oh, um," Jasmine stammers, her cheeks flushing with embarrassment as she begins to answer Thomas' question. "Well, the two types of citizen-saboteurs mentioned are the man who is not technically trained and employed, and the man who is a technician such as a lathe operator or an automobile mechanic." She pauses for a moment, her eyes darting around the room as if she's afraid someone might overhear her. "I hope I'm answering your question properly, um, Thomas," she adds, her voice barely audible.
Thomas: "You're doing great," Thomas encourages her, leaning forward slightly to better hear her soft-spoken words. "Now, if you could, could you tell me how the technical training of the saboteur affects the kind of suggestions he needs?"

The man who is not technically trained needs specific suggestions on what he can and should destroy, as well as details on the tools necessary for destruction. The man who is a technician already has the necessary skills and knowledge, but needs to be stimulated to reorient his thinking in the direction of destruction." She bites her lip, her eyes dropping to the floor as she finishes her answer.
Thomas: "That's very interesting," Thomas nods, his tone still gentle and encouraging. "Now, one last question: Which media are suggested as means of communicating suggestions and information about simple sabotage?"
Jasmine O'Hara: "Oh, um, well," Jasmine stammers, her cheeks flushing with embarrassment as she hesitates for a moment. What are the two types of citizen-saboteurs mentioned?
The two types of citizen-saboteurs mentioned are the man who is not technically trained and employed, and the man who is a technician such as a lathe operator or an automobile mechanic.

(b) Among the potential citizen-saboteurs who are to engage in physical destruction, two extreme types may be distinguished. On the one hand, there is the man who is not technically trained and employed. This man needs specific suggestions as to what he can and should destroy as well as details regarding the tools by means of which destruction is accomplished. (c) At the other extreme is the man who is a technician, such as a lathe operator or an automobile mechanic. Presumably this man would be able to devise methods of simple sabotage which would be appropriate to his own facilities. However, this man needs to be stimulated to re-orient his thinking in the direction of destruction. Specific examples, which need not be from his own field, should accomplish this. (d) Various media may be used to disseminate suggestions and information regarding simple sabotage. Among the media which may be used, as the immediate situation dictates, are: freedom stations or radio false (unreadable) broadcasts or leaflets may be directed toward specific geographic or occupational areas, or they may be general in scope. Finally, agents may be trained in the art of simple sabotage, in anticipation of a time when they may be able to communicate this information directly. (3) _Safety Measures_ (a) The amount of activity carried on by the saboteur will be governed not only by the number of opportunities he sees, but also by the amount of danger he feels. Bad news travels fast, and simple sabotage will be discouraged if too many simple saboteurs are arrested.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
